subject: Re: [junit] junit4: Exceptions in TestListener
msgSnippet: Elliotte, A valid point.  Perhaps it would be better to have a removeListener method, as you mentioned before--that way, if a listener knew it wasn t going to
messageBody:
Elliotte,

A valid point. Perhaps it would be better to have a removeListener
method, as you mentioned before--that way, if a listener knew it wasn't
going to be able to continue, it could remove itself from consideration,
and the runner could decide whether there were any listeners left, and
whether to continue. I think this would be better than having declared
exceptions in a listener interface. Asking a framework to call me back,
and then throwing an exception, feels as rude as asking a person to call
me back, and then disconnecting my number. How does that sound?

David Saff

Elliotte Rusty Harold wrote:

> David Saff wrote:
> > Elliotte,
> >
> > What would you expect the test runner to do if it caught one of these
> > exceptions? In general, I would expect that listeners should not
> > interrupt the test execution: if they find themselves unable to do what
> > they want, they should quietly deal with it on their own.
> >
>
> Somebody has to listen or there's not much point to running the tests.
> If the sole listener has an encountered an unrecoverable error, there's
> not much point to continuing. Possibly that's not the case if there are
> multiple listeners, but I think a single listener is the vast majority
> of use cases.
>
>
